name: Formal Sector Placement (Apprenticeship)
assumption_rationale:
VALIDATED with RWF's actual apprentice outcomes tracking (Nov 2025), replacing previous MSDE administrative estimate of 75%. RWF's direct operational data addresses concerns about reporting bias and cream-skimming in MSDE numbers.
This represents the empirically observed placement rate from their program implementation
plain_explanation: 72% of completers get formal jobs (RWF actual data Nov 2025). **Model application:** Expected wage = 0.72 × formal_wage × (1+premium) + 0.28 × informal_wage. Compared to control's 10% formal rate, this 62-percentage-point improvement is the PRIMARY driver of apprenticeship NPV. The 72% formal access matters MORE than the vocational wage premium because it gives 7.2× higher access to the 2.25× formal multiplier.
notes: VALIDATED WITH RWF ACTUAL DATA (72%). Replaces MSDE 75% estimate. Combined with 85% completion: P(Formal|Started) = 61.2%. NO EXTERNAL VALIDATION found in MSDE reports. The 72% vs 10% differential (7.2× improvement) is the dominant NPV driver—more impactful than wage premiums. Tracer study recommended for external validation.
source_names: RWF internal data; [1] dgt_msde_2024_tracer_study_iti_employment_outcomes.pdf; [3] 2023_tracer_study_iti_graduates.pdf; [4] ILO_2022_good_practices_apprenticeships_india.pdf; NPC Evaluation of NAPS (2021); Apprentices Act 1961 Section 18.

name: Formal Sector Entry Probability (RTE Graduates)
fromula: E[Wage_RTE] = P_FORMAL_RTE × (formal_wage × mincer_premium) + (1-P_FORMAL_RTE) × (informal_wage × mincer_premium). With P=0.30: 30% formal, 70% informal, both with 6.7% education quality premium.
assumption_rationale: NEW Jan 2026 (Anand guidance): RTE graduates from quality private schools have higher formal sector entry than national 9.1% baseline. Rationale: (1) Selection effects in RTE families, (2) Urban concentration of RTE schools, (3) Private school networks and credential signaling. Anand/Shipra guidance: 70% too high, 30-40% defensible.
plain_explanation: 30% of RTE graduates enter formal sector (vs 9.1% national baseline). This 3.3x improvement reflects: private school quality, family motivation, urban networks. Combined with Mincer premium (6.7% from education quality), creates substantial wage differential.
notes: NEW Jan 2026: Separate parameter for RTE formal entry (was using national baseline 9.1%). Range 20-50% reflects uncertainty: 20% = minimal selection effect, 30% = moderate (RECOMMENDED), 50% = strong selection and network effects. Anand capped at 50% (70% rejected as too high).
source_names: RWF Assumption based on Anand guidance Dec 2025; Selection effects literature

name: Mincer Return (Higher Secondary)
fromula: 5% (lowest quantile) to 9% (highest quantile). Midpoint 7%. Mitra (2019) via Chen et al. (2022):
assumption_rationale: Chen et al. (2022) using PLFS 2018-19 reports 5.8% for regular/salaried workers. This is methodologically consistent with our PLFS 2023-24 wage data. Mitra (2011-12) quantile regression shows 5-9% range. Historical estimates (Duraisamy 1993, Agrawal 2005) showed 9-12% but reflect pre-expansion education market.
plain_explanation: Each additional year of higher secondary education increases wages by ~5.8% for formal sector workers. Returns are much lower (even negative) for informal/casual workers, explaining why formal sector access is the key driver of intervention value.
notes: CRITICAL: Returns differ by employment type (Chen et al.): Regular 5.8%, Self-employed 2.7%, Casual -1.4%. Declining trend over time reflects educational expansion outpacing formal job creation. Range 5-8% captures quantile heterogeneity (Mitra) while excluding outdated 9%+ estimates.
source_names: Chen et al. 2022 (PLFS 2018-19); Duraisamy 2002; Agrawal 2012 (IHDS); Mitra 2019

name: Real Wage Growth Rate (Formal Sector)
fromula: wage_t = wage_0 × (1 + 0.015)^t. At t=40: wage = wage_0 × 1.81 (81% cumulative growth)
assumption_rationale: NEW Jan 2026 (Anand guidance): Formal sector workers see career progression through promotions (every 3-5 years), seniority increments (5-7% nominal = 1-2% real), and skill acquisition. Even during PLFS 2020-24 aggregate stagnation, formal workers progressed within firms.
plain_explanation: Formal workers see 1.5% annual real wage growth. Over 40-year career: wages grow 81% in real terms. Reflects: promotions, seniority increments, EPF accumulation, union bargaining.
notes: NEW Jan 2026: Sector-specific growth rate. Range 0.5-2.5% captures: 0.5% (minimal progression), 1.5% (moderate with promotions), 2.5% (strong career growth). Growing inequality evidence: Gini 35.7 (2011) → 47.9 (2021).
source_names: PLFS 2020-24 formal sector trends; India inequality literature; Anand guidance Dec 2025

name: Apprenticeship Intervention Initial Wage Premium
fromula:
Premium = [Expected Wage Treatment] - [Expected Wage Control]

Treatment pathway (WITH apprenticeship):
  E[W_treatment] = P(F|App) × W_formal + (1-P(F|App)) × W_informal


Control pathway (WITHOUT apprenticeship):
  E[W_control] = P(F|NoTrain) × W_formal + (1-P(F|NoTrain)) × W_informal


W_formal = ₹18,500 (PLFS 2023-24)
W_informal = ₹18,500 / 2.25 = ₹8,222
P(F|App) = 0.72
P(F|NoTrain) = 0.09
assumption_rationale: E[W_treatment] - E[W_control] using P(F|App)=0.72, P(F|NoTrain)=0.09, formal multiplier=2.25x. W_formal=₹18,500/mo from PLFS 2023-24 rural male secondary-educated workers.
plain_explanation: Annual wage advantage for apprenticeship graduates vs untrained peers, accounting for differential formal sector entry rates (72% vs 9%) and formal-informal wage gap (2.25x).
notes: Stress-tested Jan 2025. Wage levels updated to PLFS 2023-24. Original ₹84,000 validated within range. Sensitivity: ₹69K-85K based on P(F|App) range 65-78%.

name: RTE Private School Test Score Gain
fromula: equivalent_years = 0.23 × TEST_SCORE_TO_YEARS = 0.23 × 6.8 = 1.56 years → wage_premium = exp(MINCER × 1.56) = exp(0.07 × 1.56) = 1.115 (+11.5%)
assumption_rationale: Based on NBER RCT (w19441) in Andhra Pradesh showing 0.23 SD test score gain from private school attendance. VALIDATED Jan 2026: Core 0.23 SD value confirmed. TIER 1 weakness: External validity uncertain—AP private schools may differ from other states.
plain_explanation: Private school students score 0.23 SD higher on tests. **MODEL CHAIN: 0.23 SD × 6.8 years/SD = 1.56 equivalent years → exp(0.07 × 1.56) = 11.5% wage premium.** However, with only 9.1% reaching formal employment, this premium mostly applies to informal wages (90.9% of graduates). The test score → earnings chain: 0.23 SD → 1.56 years → 11.5% premium → weighted by P_FORMAL for expected wage.
notes: VALIDATED Jan 2026. MODEL CHAIN: test_score (0.23 SD) × conversion (6.8) = equivalent_years (1.56) → exp(Mincer × years) = wage_premium (1.115). ITT alternative: 0.137 SD would yield 0.93 years → 6.7% premium. Subject heterogeneity: Hindi 0.55 SD, English 0.12 SD, Math 0 SD. Range 0.10-0.35 reflects tier variation.

name: Test Score to Years of Schooling Conversion Factor
fromula: equivalent_years = RTE_TEST_SCORE_GAIN × 6.8 → wage_premium = exp(MINCER_RETURN_HS × equivalent_years) = exp(0.07 × 1.56) = 1.115
assumption_rationale: Updated Jan 2026: Angrist & Evans (2020) report range of 4.7-6.8 years/SD based on rescaling analysis. Using 6.8 as updated estimate per micro-LAYS methodology. India-specific NOT available but more current conversion factor improves accuracy.
plain_explanation: This parameter bridges test scores to wages. **Complete model chain: 0.23 SD test gain × 6.8 years/SD = 1.56 equivalent years → Mincer equation → exp(0.07 × 1.56) = 11.5% wage boost.** The 6.8 value (vs previous 4.7) means each SD of test improvement translates to more equivalent schooling. CAVEAT: Assumes test scores → degree completion, but employers see credentials, not scores.
notes: UPDATED Jan 2026: Value 4.7→6.8, Range 4.0-8.0. For RTE: 0.23 × 6.8 = 1.56 years (vs old 1.08). Combined with Mincer 7%: wage premium = 11.5% (vs old 6.5%). India-specific NOT AVAILABLE. CONCERN: Missing link between test scores and actual completion rates—effect only realized if higher scores → higher graduation rates.

name: Experience Premium (Linear)
assumption_rationale: Estimated from PLFS 2023-24 by regressing log(wage) on years of experience for workers with higher secondary education, controlling for gender and urban/rural. The 0.885%/year is dramatically lower than literature values (4-6%).
plain_explanation: Each year of work experience adds only 0.885% to wages—a collapse of 78% from historical estimates. This means wages grow very slowly even with experience: a worker's salary barely increases over their career.
notes: MAJOR FINDING: Experience premiums collapsed 78% from literature (0.04-0.06). Reflects wage stagnation in informal sector, flat profiles in formal sector, youth not seeing wage growth older cohorts experienced. Peak earnings occur later (age 50-55) vs earlier (40-45).

name: Apprenticeship Wage Premium Decay Half-Life
fromula: premium_t = APPRENTICE_INITIAL_PREMIUM × exp(-ln(2) × t / 10). At t=10: premium = 0.5 × initial. At t=20: premium = 0.25 × initial.
assumption_rationale: No India-specific longitudinal data exists. International proxies suggest 15-20 years for well-designed programs (Colombia JeA: 15+ years sustained; Germany dual system: 15-20 years). Conservative 12-year estimate reflects: (1) NATS is structured formal program suggesting career lock-in effect, (2) uncertainty about India labor market dynamics, (3) potential faster skill obsolescence in rapidly changing sectors.
plain_explanation: After completing apprenticeship, the wage advantage decays over time as skills become outdated. A 12-year half-life means the premium halves every 12 years. International evidence suggests well-designed programs maintain benefits for 15-20 years; we use 12 years as a conservative estimate for India given limited local data.
notes: TIER 1 GAP: No India-specific longitudinal studies. International evidence suggests: Colombia (15+ years), Germany (15-20 years). Range captures skill depreciation (5 years) to permanent career lock-in (50 years). The 12-year central value is conservative relative to international benchmarks but acknowledges uncertainty about NATS quality and India labor market dynamics.

name: Experience Premium (Quadratic)
assumption_rationale: Estimated from PLFS 2023-24 age-wage profiles. The negative value captures diminishing returns to experience—wages grow more slowly as careers progress. Less negative than literature (-0.001), indicating flatter wage profiles.
plain_explanation: Wages grow more slowly as you get older—this quadratic term captures that 'flattening' effect. The very small negative value means Indian wage profiles are flatter than in other countries.
notes: Less negative than literature (-0.001), indicating less concavity. Wage-age profile flatter overall: peak earnings occur later, less decline post-peak. Combined with low β₂, overall earnings growth is minimal. LOW impact on NPV relative to β₁ and β₂.

name: Apprenticeship Monthly Stipend
fromula: Gazette notification 2019: ₹5,000-9,000/mo based on educational qualification
assumption_rationale: Updated Jan 2026: Per Gazette notification dated 25th September 2019 (Table 5.50 in MSDE Report). Stipend rates by education: Class 5-9 pass: ₹5000; Class 10 pass: ₹6000; Class 12 pass: ₹7000; Certificate/Diploma: ₹8000; Graduate: ₹9000. Midpoint ₹7000 used.
plain_explanation: Apprentices receive about ₹7,000 per month during their training year—less than they could earn in informal work, but they gain valuable skills and a much better chance at a formal sector job. Updated from ₹10,000 based on validated Gazette rates.
notes: UPDATED Jan 2026: Value ₹10,000→₹7,000. Range ₹7,500-12,500→₹5,000-9,000. Source: Gazette notification 2019. Rates by qualification: Class 5-9: ₹5k; Class 10: ₹6k; Class 12: ₹7k; Certificate: ₹8k; Graduate: ₹9k. Government reimburses 25% (max ₹1,500/mo). Annual: ₹7,000×12=₹84,000/year.

name: [DEPRECATED] Formal vs. Informal Wage Multiplier (Total Compensation)
fromula: [DEPRECATED Jan 2026] benefits_adjustment ELIMINATED. PLFS wages are now SSOT: Urban Male Formal ₹32,800 / Informal ₹13,425 = 2.44× embedded ratio.
assumption_rationale: [DEPRECATED] Jan 2026: Anand guidance - model was over-specified. PLFS wages ALREADY differentiate by sector (2.44× ratio exceeds ILO 2.25× target). No additional benefits_adjustment needed. Parameter retained for documentation only - NOT used in calculations.
plain_explanation: [DEPRECATED] Previously used to adjust formal sector wages by 1.21× (= 2.25/1.86). ELIMINATED because PLFS wages already capture formal/informal differential. Model now uses PLFS wages directly as Single Source of Truth.
notes: DEPRECATED Jan 2026: benefits_adjustment = target_ratio / embedded_ratio NO LONGER APPLIED. Reason: Over-specification - 3 inconsistent data sources (PLFS formal wage, PLFS informal wage, ILO multiplier). PLFS embedded ratio (2.44×) already exceeds ILO target (2.25×). Keeping 2.25× inflated formal wages by 21%.
source_names: ILO India Wage Report 2018; ILO Global Wage Report 2024-25; Akhter & Negi (2022) formality wage decomposition

name: Formal Sector Entry Probability (Higher Secondary)
fromula: E[Wage] = P_FORMAL_HS × (base_wage × education_premium) + (1-P_FORMAL_HS) × (informal_wage × education_premium). With P=0.091: 9.1% get formal benefits, 90.9% stay informal.
assumption_rationale: Updated Jan 2026: ILO India Employment Report 2024 shows only 9.1% of youth with secondary/higher secondary education were in formal employment in 2022. This is the NATIONAL BASELINE for HS graduates (control group).
plain_explanation: Only 9.1% of HS graduates get formal jobs (ILO 2024). This is the NATIONAL BASELINE used for control group calculations. For RTE graduates, use P_FORMAL_RTE instead (higher due to selection effects and private school networks).
notes: UPDATE Jan 2026: Value corrected to 0.091 (was incorrectly showing 0.3). This is NATIONAL BASELINE for control group. State variation: Bihar ~3%, Bangalore ~15%. Compare: 36.1% formal for college graduates. RTE graduates use separate P_FORMAL_RTE parameter.

name: Formal Sector Entry Probability (Secondary)
assumption_rationale: Estimated from PLFS 2023-24 data, lower than higher secondary (0.20) as expected. Used for counterfactual scenarios modeling RTE dropouts who complete only 10th grade.
plain_explanation: Youth with only 10th grade have about 12% chance of formal employment—lower than 12th grade (20%), showing the value of completing higher secondary education.
notes: Lower than higher secondary (20%). Used for counterfactual scenarios (e.g. RTE dropouts completing only 10th grade).

name: Real Wage Growth Rate (Informal Sector)
fromula: wage_t = wage_0 × (1 - 0.002)^t. At t=40: wage = wage_0 × 0.92 (8% cumulative decline)
assumption_rationale: NEW Jan 2026 (Anand guidance): Informal sector wages stagnate or decline due to: no structured progression, competition from younger/cheaper workers, automation pressure, no inflation adjustment in cash payments. Growing inequality means informal falls behind.
plain_explanation: Informal workers see -0.2% annual real wage growth (slight decline). Over 40-year career: wages decline 8% in real terms. No promotions, no unions, replaced by younger workers.
notes: NEW Jan 2026: Sector-specific growth rate. Range -1.0% to +0.5% captures: -1.0% (gig economy race-to-bottom), -0.2% (moderate decline), +0.5% (rare high-growth periods). May be negative due to oversupply of low-skilled labor.
source_names: PLFS 2020-24 informal stagnation; India inequality literature; Anand guidance Dec 2025

name: Formal Sector Entry Probability (Youth Without Vocational Training)
fromula: PLFS 2023-24 youth 18-25 without vocational training. formal/total = 10%
assumption_rationale: Derived from PLFS employment distribution for youth age 18-25 with 10th/12th pass but NO vocational certification. This is the COUNTERFACTUAL for apprenticeship—what happens without intervention.
plain_explanation: Without any training, only 10% of youth get formal jobs—so apprenticeship's 72% placement rate represents a 62 percentage point improvement. If this baseline were actually 15%, the apprenticeship effect would be overstated.
notes:
This is the COUNTERFACTUAL for apprenticeship. The probability of youth without vocational training entering the formal sector in India is 9.1% as of 2022. This probability is lower compared to those with formal or informal vocational training, which stands at 13.2% and 11.2%, respectively. 

Regarding regional variations, the probability of formal sector entry for youths without vocational training varies significantly across regions. For instance, in 2022, the probability was higher in the South (12.3%) and West (12.7%) compared to the Central (9.4%), East (8.6%), and North (6.0%) regions.

name: Social Discount Rate
assumption_rationale: Updated Jan 2026: Murty & Panda (2020) derive 8.5% using original Ramsey formula (p + vg) for Indian public sector projects. Alternative extended formula yields 6%. The 8.5% is used as primary estimate for long-run investment projects.
plain_explanation: Future earnings are worth less than today's earnings—this 8.5% rate determines how much we 'discount' benefits that occur 20-40 years from now. Updated from 3.72% based on validated source analysis.
notes: UPDATED Jan 2026: Value 3.72%→8.5%, Range 3-8%→6-10%. Murty & Panda (2020) derive: 8.5% (original Ramsey), 6% (extended with precautionary effect). For long-run investment projects, 8.5% appropriate. Term structure: 8% for 30yr projects, declining for longer horizons. Higher rate = more conservative NPV estimates.

name: Real Wage Growth Rate [DEPRECATED]
assumption_rationale: [DEPRECATED] Use REAL_WAGE_GROWTH_FORMAL and REAL_WAGE_GROWTH_INFORMAL instead. This single rate was replaced Jan 2026 to model growing inequality between sectors.
plain_explanation: [DEPRECATED] Replaced by sector-specific growth rates. Formal sector sees 1.5%/year career progression; informal stagnates or declines. See REAL_WAGE_GROWTH_FORMAL and REAL_WAGE_GROWTH_INFORMAL.
notes: DEPRECATED Jan 2026: Model now uses sector-specific rates to capture growing inequality. Formal workers get promotions and increments; informal workers face stagnation.

name: Apprenticeship Program Completion Rate [Not in model]
assumption_rationale: Based on MSDE program data showing 85% of enrolled apprentices complete their training. This is independent of the 72% placement rate—completion measures who finishes training, not who gets a formal job afterward.
plain_explanation: 15% of apprentices drop out before finishing—so for every 100 enrolled, only 85 complete training and become eligible for formal job placement. The remaining 15% leave due to low stipends, employer mismatches, or family financial pressures.
notes: TIER 1 GAP: MSDE tracks but doesn't publish dropout rates. Trade variation: Manufacturing/engineering (80-90% completion), Services/hospitality (70-80%). Combined effect: P(Formal|Started) = 0.72 × 0.85 = 61.2% overall placement rate. Sensitivity: Test [75%, 85%, 95%].

name: Apprenticeship Year 0 Net Opportunity Cost [DEPRECATED]
assumption_rationale: Calculated as stipend (₹120k/year) minus what the apprentice could have earned in informal work (₹168k/year per PLFS 2023-24). The negative value represents a real economic cost that must be recovered through higher post-training wages.
plain_explanation: During the training year, apprentices actually lose money compared to working informally—about ₹49,000 less. This is an investment: they sacrifice immediate earnings for better long-term job prospects.
notes: Calculation: Stipend ₹10k/mo×12=₹120k vs Counterfactual ₹14k/mo×12=₹168k. Net: -₹48k≈-₹49k. Range: Pessimistic -₹80k (urban youth), Optimistic -₹20k (rural youth with limited alternatives). Impact: Reduces LNPV by ₹45-55k (4-5% of total). Added per Anand feedback (Dec 2025).

name: Working Life Duration (Formal Sector) [Excluded from sensitivity analysis- fixed structural assumptions]
fromula: Statutory retirement age (60-62) minus typical entry age (22 for graduates)
plain_explanation:
Formal sector has defined retirement age:
 - Government: 60 years (some states 58)
 - Private: 58-60 years (EPFO rules)
 - Recent proposal to raise to 62-65 (not yet implemented)
 
 Entry age:
 - Higher secondary + college: 22 years
 - Apprenticeship: 18-20 years
 
 Use 40 years (age 22-62) as baseline for college-educated.
 Use 42-44 years for apprentices (earlier entry).

name: Rural Female Casual/Informal Wage
assumption_rationale: Directly measured from PLFS 2023-24: daily casual wage (₹299) multiplied by 25 working days per month. This is observed survey data, not estimated.
plain_explanation: The lowest wage category in our model—rural women in casual work earn about ₹7,500/month. Many rural women actually do unpaid family labor, so even this low wage represents those who find paid work.
notes: NOT varied in Monte Carlo (measured data). Lowest counterfactual wage. Many rural women in unpaid family labor (not captured here). Calculated: ₹299/day × 25 days = ₹7,475/mo.

name: Rural Female Baseline Wage (Higher Secondary, 12yr)
assumption_rationale: Derived from secondary wage (₹12,396) using the 5.8% Mincer return: ₹12,396 × (1.058)² = ₹15,558. This reflects the standard education-wage relationship from PLFS 2023-24.
plain_explanation: A rural woman with 12th grade earns about ₹15,500/month—still 53% less than an urban man with the same education. The gender and location gaps persist even at higher education levels.
notes: NOT varied in Monte Carlo (measured/derived data). Gender + rural double penalty: 53% lower than urban male (₹32,800). Calculation: ₹12,396 × 1.058² = ₹15,558.

name: Rural Female Baseline Wage (Secondary, 10yr)
assumption_rationale: Directly measured from PLFS 2023-24 Table 21 for salaried workers in regular wage employment. Represents average monthly earnings for rural females with secondary education.
plain_explanation: A rural woman with 10th grade education earns about ₹12,400/month—the lowest formal wage category, 52% below what urban men with the same education earn.
notes: NOT varied in Monte Carlo (measured data). Lowest formal wage: rural + gender gap. 52% lower than urban male (₹26,105).

name: Rural Male Casual/Informal Wage
assumption_rationale: Directly measured from PLFS 2023-24: daily casual wage (₹444) multiplied by 25 working days per month. This is observed survey data, not estimated.
plain_explanation: Rural men in casual work earn about ₹11,100/month—this is the wage floor for informal agricultural and manual labor, which is the alternative for youth who don't get formal training.
notes: NOT varied in Monte Carlo (measured data). Rural informal wage floor. Agricultural labor-dominated. Calculated: ₹444/day × 25 days = ₹11,100/mo.

name: Rural Male Baseline Wage (Higher Secondary, 12yr)
assumption_rationale: Derived from secondary wage (₹18,200) using the 5.8% Mincer return: ₹18,200 × (1.058)² = ₹22,880. This reflects the standard education-wage relationship from PLFS 2023-24.
plain_explanation: A rural man with 12th grade earns about ₹22,900/month—this is the key anchor for calculating RTE benefits in rural areas.
notes: NOT varied in Monte Carlo (measured/derived data). Key anchor for rural RTE scenarios. Calculation: ₹18,200 × 1.058² = ₹22,880.

name: Rural Male Baseline Wage (Secondary, 10yr)
assumption_rationale: Directly measured from PLFS 2023-24 Table 21 for salaried workers in regular wage employment. Represents average monthly earnings for rural males with secondary education.
plain_explanation: A rural man with 10th grade education earns about ₹18,200/month—30% less than an urban man with the same education, reflecting the persistent urban-rural wage gap.
notes: NOT varied in Monte Carlo (measured data). Urban-rural gap: 30% lower than urban male (₹26,105).

name: Urban Female Casual/Informal Wage
assumption_rationale: Directly measured from PLFS 2023-24: daily casual wage (₹365) multiplied by 25 working days per month. This is observed survey data, not estimated.
plain_explanation: Urban women in casual work earn about ₹9,100/month—32% less than urban men in similar informal jobs, showing the gender penalty even in the informal sector.
notes: NOT varied in Monte Carlo (measured data). Gender + informality double penalty: 32% lower than urban male informal (₹13,425). Calculated: ₹365/day × 25 days = ₹9,129/mo.

name: Urban Female Baseline Wage (Higher Secondary, 12yr)
assumption_rationale: Derived from secondary wage (₹19,879) using the 5.8% Mincer return: ₹19,879 × (1.058)² = ₹24,928. This reflects the standard education-wage relationship from PLFS 2023-24.
plain_explanation: An urban woman with 12th grade earns about ₹24,900/month—better than rural, but still below urban men. The gender wage gap persists even at higher education levels.
notes: NOT varied in Monte Carlo (measured/derived data). Gender wage gap persists at higher education levels. Calculation: ₹19,879 × 1.058² = ₹24,928.

name: Urban Female Baseline Wage (Secondary, 10yr)
assumption_rationale: Directly measured from PLFS 2023-24 Table 21 for salaried workers in regular wage employment. Represents average monthly earnings for urban females with secondary education.
plain_explanation: An urban woman with 10th grade education earns about ₹19,900/month—24% less than an urban man with the same education, reflecting persistent gender wage gaps.
notes: NOT varied in Monte Carlo (measured data). Gender wage gap: 24% lower than urban male (₹26,105).

name: Urban Male Casual/Informal Wage
assumption_rationale: Directly measured from PLFS 2023-24: daily casual wage (₹537) multiplied by 25 working days per month. This is observed survey data, not estimated.
plain_explanation: Urban men in casual work earn about ₹13,400/month—this is the counterfactual (what they'd earn without intervention) for young urban men considering apprenticeship.
notes: NOT varied in Monte Carlo (measured data). Counterfactual for informal sector entry. Assumes 25 working days/month. Calculated: ₹537/day × 25 days = ₹13,425/mo.

name: Urban Male Baseline Wage (Higher Secondary, 12yr)
assumption_rationale: Derived from secondary wage (₹26,105) using the 5.8% Mincer return from PLFS 2023-24. This is the education premium: each additional year of schooling adds ~5.8% to wages.
plain_explanation: An urban man with 12th grade earns about ₹32,800/month—this is the key anchor for our RTE calculations, representing what a successful RTE graduate might earn in a formal job.
notes: NOT varied in Monte Carlo (measured/derived data). Key anchor for RTE higher secondary completion scenario. Calculation: ₹26,105 × 1.058² = ₹32,800.

name: Counterfactual EWS Schooling Distribution [Not in model]
assumption_rationale: Based on ASER 2023-24 survey data showing where EWS children actually go to school without RTE intervention. Updated from previous assumptions (70/20/10) to reflect post-COVID reality.
plain_explanation: Without RTE, about 67% of poor children go to government schools, 31% attend low-fee private schools, and only 3% drop out completely. The high private school share actually raises the baseline, making RTE's impact more conservative.
notes: UPDATED from Milestone 2 (was 70/20/10). Post-COVID shift: EWS families increasingly opt for low-fee private schools. Lower dropout rates (2.6% vs 10%) reflect policy success. Higher private school share RAISES counterfactual baseline → LOWERS RTE treatment effect → More conservative/credible estimates.
source_names: asercentre.org  |   asercentre.org  |   rchiips.org  |   asercentre.org  |   mospi.nic.in  |   dashboard.udiseplus.gov.in

name: Consumer Price Index (CPI) Inflation [Not in model]
fromula: MOSPI CPI data 2025 = 4.95%. Not used in model (real terms)
assumption_rationale: Based on MOSPI official CPI data showing 4.95% average inflation in 2025. India's inflation has moderated from 10-12% (2010-2013) to 4-6% (2020-2024).
plain_explanation: Prices rise about 5% per year in India. But here's the key: we don't use this directly in our calculations because everything is already in 'real' (inflation-adjusted) terms.
notes: IMPORTANT: NOT directly used in NPV calculations. Model works in REAL terms: baseline wages already real (2025 prices), REAL_WAGE_GROWTH captures real dynamics, SOCIAL_DISCOUNT_RATE is already real. Documented to show relationship: nominal growth ≈ 5% = inflation + real growth.

name: Urban Male Baseline Wage (Secondary, 10yr)
assumption_rationale: Directly measured from PLFS 2023-24 Table 21 for salaried workers in regular wage employment. This is observed survey data from India's official labor force survey, not estimated.
plain_explanation: An urban man with 10th grade education earns about ₹26,100/month in a salaried job—this is our baseline wage from which we calculate education premiums.
notes: NOT varied in Monte Carlo (measured data). Salaried workers, regular wage employment. Base year: 2025.

name: Test Score to Equivalent Years of Schooling [Not in model]
fromula: Angrist et al. 2021 World Bank = 4.7 years/SD
assumption_rationale: Based on World Bank LMIC meta-analysis (Angrist et al. 2021). No India-specific estimate available. Converts: 0.23 SD test score gain × 4.7 = 1.08 equivalent years of schooling.
plain_explanation: A 1 standard deviation improvement in test scores is worth about 4.7 years of schooling in terms of future earnings. So RTE's 0.23 SD gain translates to roughly 1 extra year of 'effective' education.
notes: Global LMIC average. India-specific NOT available. Converts 0.23 SD × 4.7 = 1.08 equivalent years. CONCERN: Assumes test scores → degree completion. Employers see credentials, not scores. Missing link: Do RTE students have higher completion rates?

name: RTE Intervention Initial Wage Premium [DEPRECATED]
assumption_rationale: Calculated as difference between treatment (private school → formal job) and counterfactual (weighted average of government school, low-fee private, and dropout outcomes). Uses updated ASER 2023-24 counterfactual distribution.
plain_explanation: RTE students earn about ₹98,000 more per year than similar kids without RTE access—that's the combined effect of better education quality and higher chances of formal employment.
notes: Calculation (Urban Male): Treatment ₹32,800/mo × P(Formal)=0.20 × 2.25 = ₹14,760/mo effective. Control (ASER 2023-24 weighted): Govt 66.8%, low-fee private 30.6%, dropout 2.6% = ₹6,600/mo effective. Premium: (₹14,760 - ₹6,600) × 12 = ₹98k/year. Within 40Hour_PoC_Plan range (₹80-120k).

name: RTE Program Retention Through Grade 12 [Not in model]
assumption_rationale: TIER 1 GAP: No longitudinal tracking of RTE beneficiaries exists. The 60% assumes RTE students have same retention as private school average—this LIKELY OVERESTIMATES if RTE students face discrimination or hidden costs.
plain_explanation: Only about 60% of RTE students make it through to 12th grade completion. Combined with the 29% seat fill rate, this means only 17% of eligible children get the full RTE benefit.
notes: TIER 1 GAP: No RTE-specific tracking. Assumption may OVERESTIMATE if RTE students face discrimination/isolation, hidden costs, lower-quality treatment. Transition stages: Grade 1-8 (70-85%), 8-10 (70-85%), 10-12 (70-85%) → Overall 60%. Regional: Urban South/West 65-75%, Rural North/East 50-60%. Program effectiveness = 29% × 60% = 17.4%.

name: RTE 25% Quota Seat Fill Rate [Not in model]
assumption_rationale: Based on CAG Audit Report 2014 showing only 29% of reserved seats actually filled nationwide. Data is dated but no recent comprehensive audit exists. State variation is huge: Punjab 48%, Bihar 11%.
plain_explanation: Only 29% of RTE reserved seats are actually filled—most eligible families don't apply due to awareness gaps, documentation barriers, or practical challenges. This dramatically affects the program's overall cost-effectiveness.
notes: CRITICAL PROGRAM PARAMETER. State variation: Punjab 48%, Bihar 11%, national 29%. Data limitations: CAG audit dated (2013-14), may reflect awareness/application barriers, state-specific data requires special requests. Effective program reach = Fill rate × Retention = 29% × 60% = 17.4%.

name: Vocational Training Wage Premium [DEPRECATED]
fromula: DGT National Tracer Study 2019-20. trained_wage / untrained_wage - 1 = 4.7%
assumption_rationale: Based on DGT National Tracer Study 2019-20 using ITI graduates as proxy for apprenticeship completers. The 4.7% premium is cross-sectional—no data on persistence over time.
plain_explanation: Vocational training adds about 4.7% to wages on top of formal sector benefits. Combined with the 2× formal sector multiplier, this means trained workers earn significantly more than untrained counterparts.
notes: Cross-sectional premium for formal vocational training. Combines with formal multiplier: Informal ₹11,100/mo → Formal without vocational ₹11,100×2.25=₹24,975/mo → Formal WITH vocational ₹24,975×1.047=₹26,150/mo. LIMITATION: No data on persistence (does premium decay over time?).

name: Labor Market Entry Age [Excluded from sensitivity analysis- fixed structural assumptions]
assumption_rationale: Standard assumption for when higher secondary graduates enter the formal labor market, accounting for job search time. This sets the base year for NPV discounting—we calculate lifetime earnings from this point forward.
plain_explanation: We assume most graduates start their careers around age 22—after finishing 12th grade, possibly some additional training, and job search. RTE kids enrolling at age 6 today will hit the job market around 2041.
notes: Variation by pathway: Apprenticeship 18-20 years, Higher secondary only 20-22 years, College graduates 22-25 years. Affects NPV base year. For RTE: Child enrolls age 6 (2025) → Completes HS age 18 (2037) → Enters labor market age 22 (2041). See discounting_methodology_explanation.md.

name: Working Life Duration (Informal Sector) [DEPRECATED]
fromula: No retirement - work until 65-70. Entry 15-18yr = ~50 years
assumption_rationale: Based on e-Shram portal data and PLFS elderly employment rates. Informal workers have no fixed retirement age and often work until physically unable—typically age 15-18 to 65-70+, driven by lack of pensions and social security.
plain_explanation: Informal sector workers have no retirement—they work as long as physically possible, often into their late 60s or 70s. That's about 50 years of work, but later years have reduced productivity and income.
notes: Informal sector has NO fixed retirement. Entry often 15-18 years (early dropout). Exit: Work as long as able (65-70+). Driven by lack of pensions, savings, social security. CAVEAT: Later years (60+) likely reduced productivity/income. Model should apply productivity discount factor (e.g., 0.5× after age 65).

name: Test Score to Equivalent Years of Schooling [Not in model]
fromula: World Bank LMIC meta-analysis (Angrist et al. 2021)
plain_explanation:
Global LMIC average. India-specific estimate not available.
 
 Converts: 0.23 SD × 4.7 years/SD = 1.08 equivalent years.
 
 Concern: This conversion assumes test scores → actual degree completion.
 Employers see credentials (degrees), not test scores.
 Effect only realized if test score gains → higher secondary/college completion.
 
 Missing link: Do RTE students have higher completion rates?

name: RTE Intervention Initial Wage Premium [DEPRECATED]
fromula: (Private school formal wage - Counterfactual weighted avg) at labor market entry
plain_explanation:
Calculation (Urban Male example):
 - Treatment: ₹32,800/mo × P(Formal|HS)=0.20 × 2.25 formal multiplier = ₹14,760/mo effective
 - Control: Weighted avg of govt (66.8%), low-fee private (30.6%), dropout (2.6%)
 = 0.668×₹26,105×0.12×2.25 + 0.306×₹29,000×0.15×2.25 + 0.026×₹13,425
 = ₹6,600/mo effective
 - Premium: (₹14,760 - ₹6,600) × 12 = ₹98,000/year
 
 This is WITHIN the 40Hour_PoC_Plan range (₹80-120k) but at upper end.
 
 Updated counterfactual from Milestone 2:
 - Govt: 66.8% (was 70%)
 - Low-fee private: 30.6% (was 20%)
 - Dropout: 2.6% (was 10%)
 
 Higher private school share in counterfactual RAISES the control group baseline,
 thus LOWERS the treatment effect.

name: RTE Program Retention Through Grade 12 [Not in model]
fromula: UDISE+ EWS completion rates as proxy (no RTE-specific tracking)
plain_explanation:
TIER 1 GAP: No longitudinal tracking of RTE beneficiaries exists.
 
 Assumption: RTE students have same retention as private school average.
 This LIKELY OVERESTIMATES if:
 - RTE students face discrimination/social isolation
 - Families still can't afford textbooks/transport/uniform
 - Schools provide lower quality education to RTE students
 
 Transition stages:
 - Grade 1-8: 70-85% retention
 - Grade 8-10: 70-85% continuation 
 - Grade 10-12: 70-85% continuation
 - Overall: 60% complete Grade 12
 
 Regional variation (ASER):
 - Urban South/West: 65-75%
 - Rural North/East: 50-60%
 
 MODEL IMPACT:
 Program effectiveness = Fill rate × Retention
 29% × 60% = 17.4% effective reach
 
 This is CRITICAL for realistic BCR estimates.

name: RTE 25% Quota Seat Fill Rate [Not in model]
fromula: CAG Audit Report 2014 on RTE Implementation
plain_explanation:
CRITICAL PROGRAM PARAMETER: Only 29% of reserved seats actually filled.
 
 State variation: 10-50% (Punjab: 48%, Bihar: 11%, national: 29%)
 
 Data limitations:
 - CAG audit is dated (2013-14), but no recent comprehensive audit
 - May reflect awareness/application barriers, not demand
 - State-specific data requires special requests from education departments
 
 IMPLICATION: Effective program reach = Fill rate × Retention rate
 If 29% fill and 60% retention → only 17.4% of eligible children get full treatment.
 
 This affects BCR calculation:
 - Per-completer BCR: LNPV / Cost_per_completer
 - Per-eligible BCR: (LNPV × Fill × Retention) / Cost_per_eligible

name: Vocational Training Wage Premium [DEPRECATED]
fromula: DGT National Tracer Study 2019-20 (ITI graduates proxy)
plain_explanation:
Cross-sectional premium for formal vocational training.
 
 Combines with formal sector multiplier:
 - Informal wage: ₹11,100/mo (rural male)
 - Formal wage without vocational: ₹11,100 × 2.25 = ₹24,975/mo
 - Formal wage WITH vocational: ₹24,975 × 1.047 = ₹26,150/mo
 
 Limitation: No data on persistence (does premium decay over time?).

name: Working Life Duration (Formal Sector) [Excluded from sensitivity analysis- fixed structural assumptions]
assumption_rationale: Based on statutory retirement ages: Government 60 years (some states 58), Private 58-60 years (EPFO rules). Entry age for college-educated is typically 22 years, giving 40 years of formal sector working life.
plain_explanation: Formal sector workers have defined career spans—typically age 22 to 62, about 40 years. This is shorter than informal sector because of mandatory retirement ages.
notes: Formal sector has defined retirement: Government 60 (some states 58), Private 58-60 (EPFO). Recent proposal to raise to 62-65 (not yet implemented). Entry age: HS+college 22yr, Apprenticeship 18-20yr. Use 40yr (age 22-62) for college-educated, 42-44yr for apprentices (earlier entry).

name: Working Life Duration (Informal Sector) [DEPRECATED]
fromula: e-Shram portal data + PLFS elderly employment rates
plain_explanation:
Informal sector has NO fixed retirement:
 - Entry: Often 15-18 years (child labor, early school dropout)
 - Exit: Work as long as physically able (65-70+)
 - Driven by lack of pensions, savings, social security
 
 Caveat: Later years (60+) likely reduced productivity/income.
 Model should apply productivity discount factor (e.g., 0.5× after age 65).
